description: A Critical Alarm has occurred in a Power Chain Device.
Alarm and source information are contained in the OBJECTS.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD EATON-PXG-MIB::powerChainCriticalAlarmEvent EATON-PXG-MIB::eventID i 9999 EATON-PXG-MIB::eventSequenceIndex i 9999 EATON-PXG-MIB::eventDescription s EXAMPLE EATON-PXG-MIB::eventValue s EXAMPLE ENTITY-MIB::entPhysicalName s EXAMPLE

description: A unique identifier for the event.
variables.name: EATON-PXG-MIB::eventID

description: A unique identifier for a sequence of events
using the same EventId.
variables.name: EATON-PXG-MIB::eventSequenceIndex

description: A human-readable text description of the Event or Alarm.
variables.name: EATON-PXG-MIB::eventDescription

description: A human-readable text representation of the source and
value of the node that caused the Event or Alarm.
This text should be of the form 'SourcePath = Value'
where SourcePath is the address of the node within the
BACnetWS+ node tree, as accessed with web service calls.
variables.name: EATON-PXG-MIB::eventValue

description: The textual name of the physical entity. The value of this
object should be the name of the component as assigned by
the local device and should be suitable for use in commands
entered at the device's 'console'. This might be a text
name (e.g., 'console') or a simple component number (e.g.
port or module number, such as '1'), depending on the
physical component naming syntax of the device.
If there is no local name, or if this object is otherwise
not applicable, then this object contains a zero-length
string.
Note that the value of entPhysicalName for two physical
entities will be the same in the event that the console
interface does not distinguish between them, e.g., slot-1
and the card in slot-1.
variables.name: ENTITY-MIB::entPhysicalName

description: A Cautionary Alarm has occurred in a Power Chain Device.
Alarm and source information are contained in the OBJECTS.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD EATON-PXG-MIB::powerChainCautionaryAlarmEvent EATON-PXG-MIB::eventID i 9999 EATON-PXG-MIB::eventSequenceIndex i 9999 EATON-PXG-MIB::eventDescription s EXAMPLE EATON-PXG-MIB::eventValue s EXAMPLE ENTITY-MIB::entPhysicalName s EXAMPLE

description: A user has Acknowledged a Critical or Cautionary Alarm.
This does NOT clear or 'close' a latched Alarm.
Alarm and source information are contained in the OBJECTS.

description: The condition that raised the Alarm or Event no longer exists;
the three types of Events have different outcomes:
1) A latching Alarm is still considered active and will need to be
Closed by a user Close Acknowledgement.
2) A non-latching Alarm is closed and its Alarm sequence completed.
3) An Event is closed and its Event sequence completed.
Alarm and source information are contained in the OBJECTS.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD EATON-PXG-MIB::powerChainEventCleared EATON-PXG-MIB::eventID i 9999 EATON-PXG-MIB::eventSequenceIndex i 9999 EATON-PXG-MIB::eventDescription s EXAMPLE EATON-PXG-MIB::eventValue s EXAMPLE ENTITY-MIB::entPhysicalName s EXAMPLE

description: A non-alarming Event has occurred in a Power Chain Device.
Event and source information are contained in the OBJECTS.

Summary.eval: ($v3 ne '') ? '$v3' : 'Non-alarming event occurred in a power chain device'

description: An update to the alarm entry at alarmID has occurred;
however, the alarmLevel has not changed due to this update.
This is normally seen with latching alarms when condition that caused
the alarm is removed or recurs before the alarm has been closed.
Alarm and source information are contained in the OBJECTS.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD EATON-PXG-MIB::powerChainAlarmUpdated EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmID i 9999 EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmSequenceIndex i 9999 EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmDescription s EXAMPLE EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmValue s EXAMPLE EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmLevel i 1 ENTITY-MIB::entPhysicalName s EXAMPLE

description: A unique identifier for the alarm.
This var is not-accessible when browsing the table.
variables.name: EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmID

description: A unique identifier for a sequence of alarms
using the same alarmID.
variables.name: EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmSequenceIndex

description: A human-readable text description of the Event or Alarm.
variables.name: EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmDescription

description: A human-readable text representation of the source and
value of the node that caused the Event or Alarm.
This text should be of the form 'SourcePath = Value'
where SourcePath is the address of the node within the
BACnetWS+ node tree, as accessed with web service calls.
variables.name: EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmValue

description: Enumerated value that tells the present level (status) of
an activeAlarmsEntry.
critical (1) - The alarm is at a critical level.
cautionary (2) - The alarm is at a cautionary level
(a less severe level than critical).
acknowledged (3) - The user has acknowledged, but not yet closed,
the cautionary or critical alarm.
active (4) - Not used; would be a status for an event.
cleared (5) - A transient internal level, not normally seen.
closed (6) - A transient internal level, not normally seen because
the activeAlarmsEntry is removed when closed.
unknown (7) - Alarm status is not known. Not normally seen.
variables.name: EATON-PXG-MIB::alarmLevel

description: The textual name of the physical entity. The value of this
object should be the name of the component as assigned by
the local device and should be suitable for use in commands
entered at the device's 'console'. This might be a text
name (e.g., 'console') or a simple component number (e.g.
port or module number, such as '1'), depending on the
physical component naming syntax of the device.
If there is no local name, or if this object is otherwise
not applicable, then this object contains a zero-length
string.
Note that the value of entPhysicalName for two physical
entities will be the same in the event that the console
interface does not distinguish between them, e.g., slot-1
and the card in slot-1.
variables.name: ENTITY-MIB::entPhysicalName
